body:
Hello

CPP based examples are working fine for both hello world, router guide includes CPP bases server and client, In another combination of CPP client & Python based server is OK too. It just issue of python based client is not working. I had followed instructions from http://www.grpc.io/docs/tutorials/basic/python.html 

Virtualenv and non virrtualenv did not make any difference, 

Is there additional changes or environment setting are required? Please let me know desperately looking for help.

Niren

I have the same error  just like this.

go Server + go Client -> OK
go Server + grpc-gateway + curl -> OK
go Server + Py3.5 Client -> line 445 raise _Rendezvous(state, None, None, deadline)

@nirenrc and @keekun: thank you for sharing the stack traces with us, but is that all the output emitted from your program? Was there nothing else? Anything that looks like `grpc.StatusCode.<something>` or a descriptive error message? Also have you modified the hello world code at all?

I also have issues with greeter_clint.py. greeter_server.py seems to be running..

# python greeter_client.py
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "greeter_client.py", line 48, in <module>
    run()
  File "greeter_client.py", line 43, in run
    response = stub.SayHello(helloworld_pb2.HelloRequest(name='you'))
  File "/usr/lib64/python2.7/site-packages/grpc/_channel.py", line 507, in __call__
    return _end_unary_response_blocking(state, call, False, deadline)
  File "/usr/lib64/python2.7/site-packages/grpc/_channel.py", line 455, in _end_unary_response_blocking
    raise _Rendezvous(state, None, None, deadline)
grpc._channel._Rendezvous: <_Rendezvous of RPC that terminated with (StatusCode.UNAVAILABLE, Connect Failed)>

I install grpcio tools and grpc

[root@testserver helloworld]# ps -ef |grep greeter_server
root     17900 17562  0 20:09 pts/4    00:00:00 python greeter_server.py
root     22421 17362  0 20:20 pts/2    00:00:00 grep --color=auto greeter
[root@testserver helloworld]# netstat -anp |grep 17900
tcp6       0      0 :::50051                :::*                    LISTEN      17900/python

just to show server is running...

@stevec2810: does this happen every time or just some of the time? Is the problem abated by adding `grpc.channel_ready_future(channel).result()` between the `channel = ` line and the `stub = ` line? With what version of `grpcio` are you observing the problem?

Hi. Thanks for the Help.
Installing collected packages: grpcio
Successfully installed grpcio-1.3.5
Installing collected packages: grpcio-tools
Successfully installed grpcio-tools-1.3.5
These come from pip 9.0.1
I added the mod you suggested but the client just sits there in an endless loop.

I also built from source the following version.
Installing collected packages: grpcio
  Running setup.py install for grpcio ... done
Successfully installed grpcio-1.5.0.dev0
But I get the same when I try to run the hello world client. All this is done inside a virtualenv
(src27grpc) [root@test helloworld]# python --version
Python 2.7.13
(src27grpc) [root@test helloworld]# python greeter_client.py
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "greeter_client.py", line 48, in <module>
    run()
  File "greeter_client.py", line 43, in run
    response = stub.SayHello(helloworld_pb2.HelloRequest(name='you'))
  File "/root/Downloads/src27grpc/lib/python2.7/site-packages/grpc/_channel.py", line 507, in __call__
    return _end_unary_response_blocking(state, call, False, deadline)
  File "/root/Downloads/src27grpc/lib/python2.7/site-packages/grpc/_channel.py", line 455, in _end_unary_response_blocking
    raise _Rendezvous(state, None, None, deadline)
grpc._channel._Rendezvous: <_Rendezvous of RPC that terminated with (StatusCode.UNAVAILABLE, Connect Failed)>
(src27grpc) [root@test helloworld]# netstat -anp |grep 50051
tcp        0      0 :::50051                    :::*                        LISTEN      26960/python
(src27grpc) [root@test helloworld]# ps -ef |grep  26960
root     26960 26944  0 04:02 pts/5    00:00:00 python greeter_server.py
root     27097 24903  0 04:09 pts/4    00:00:00 grep 26960
(src27grpc) [root@test helloworld]#

@stevec2810: tell us more about your platform? On what hardware and with what operating system are you working? I just went through [the Hello World exercise](http://www.grpc.io/docs/quickstart/python.html) on my Debian 8 workstation in Google Compute Engine and it worked as expected.

When I ran `greeter_client.py` without `greeter_server.py` running, I saw the `(StatusCode.UNAVAILABLE, Connect Failed)` that you're seeing. Is it possible that you've got something like a misconfigured firewall or something else preventing applications from locally connecting to other applications?

System is Centos 6.9 with python 2.7.13. I also tested it on Centos 7.2 and same issue. Iptables is stopped completely. the greeter_server appears to be running, but I don't know any way to debug this as I am completely new to it. Hardware is a VM running in VMware, 2G RAM single vcpu fairly straightforward system.

(src27grpc) [root@test helloworld]# gcc --version
gcc (GCC) 4.7.2 20121015 (Red Hat 4.7.2-5)
Copyright (C) 2012 Free Software Foundation, Inc.
This is free software; see the source for copying conditions.  There is NO
warranty; not even for MERCHANTABILITY or FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE.

(src27grpc) [root@test helloworld]# python --version
Python 2.7.13
@stevec2810: on how many different systems have you observed the problem? Do you have access to multiple systems on which to test?
I have many systems unfortunately all are either redhat/centos base.

@stevec2810: that's fine; if it's the case that our example fails on all systems of a given type that's certainly alarming information that we'd like to have confirmed. Are you able to reproduce the problem on a completely "clean" freshly-installed system? I don't know much about VMware; are you able to reproduce the problem on some system outside VMware?

vmware doesn't matter really, just think of it as a fresh server. These are brand new installs. This one is Centos 6.9 with development tools installed, upgraded GCC to 4.7 installed protocol buffers from source, built the grpcio from source..build Bazel from source..installed python 2.7 and virtualenv. this system is about as basic and brand new as I could make it.

@stevec2810: just one more sanity check: is the problem isolated to gRPC Python (or gRPC)? Are you able, in the same environment, to spin up a random HTTP server, connect to it, and get a response from it?
not sure I follow you. you want a web server running on port 80 on this server or is there some way to test gRPC from http?
So, I installed httpd and configured a simple webpage, I can connect to it, so the TCP stack and applications are working correctly

(src27grpc) [root@test Downloads]# cd grpc/examples/python/helloworld/ (src27grpc) [root@test helloworld]# python greeter_server.py & [1] 2071 (src27grpc) [root@test helloworld]# netstat -anp |grep 2071 tcp 0 0 :::50051 :::* LISTEN 2071/python (src27grpc) [root@test helloworld]# python greeter_client.py Traceback (most recent call last): File "greeter_client.py", line 48, in run() File "greeter_client.py", line 43, in run response = stub.SayHello(helloworld_pb2.HelloRequest(name='you')) File "/root/Downloads/src27grpc/lib/python2.7/site-packages/grpc/_channel.py", line 507, in __call__ return _end_unary_response_blocking(state, call, False, deadline) File "/root/Downloads/src27grpc/lib/python2.7/site-packages/grpc/_channel.py", line 455, in _end_unary_response_blocking raise _Rendezvous(state, None, None, deadline) grpc._channel._Rendezvous: <_Rendezvous of RPC that terminated with (StatusCode.UNAVAILABLE, Connect Failed)> (src27grpc) [root@test helloworld]# telnet localhost 80 Trying ::1... Connected to localhost. Escape character is '^]'. GET /index.htm HTTP/1.1 host: localhost you can see here the hosted page, and the servers running on the port. is there anyway to send a command to the server on the telnet port 50051? just to test it HTTP/1.1 200 OK Date: Fri, 02 Jun 2017 08:41:00 GMT Server: Apache/2.2.15 (CentOS) Last-Modified: Fri, 02 Jun 2017 08:35:59 GMT ETag: "a5b3f-c3-550f60af3cb9c" Accept-Ranges: bytes Content-Length: 195 Connection: close Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8 Test Page
Hello Google

Testing

Connection closed by foreign host. (src27grpc) [root@test helloworld]#

@stevec2810: on Google Compute Engine, using both the GCE-provided CentOS 7 and RHEL 7 images, the following works for me (prints `Greeter client received: Hello, you!`) in brand-new virtual machines:
```
sudo yum install git python-virtualenv
virtualenv venv
venv/bin/pip install --upgrade pip
venv/bin/pip install --upgrade grpcio grpcio-tools
git clone https://github.com/grpc/grpc
cd grpc/examples/python/helloworld
../../../../venv/bin/python greeter_server.py &
../../../../venv/bin/python greeter_client.py
```
. Do you have access to virtual machines on Google Compute Engine? If so, do those exact steps work for you?

ahh, no I don't have a cloud compute account.

I was trying to build a gRPC server inside my network. I don't really have access to the cloud from inside the network. so I would need to be able to produce a working gRPC server without using your image. I can see there is probably something in your environment that I don't have.

@stevec2810: I'm starting to run out of ideas but since you mentioned having built from source, are you able to run the tests? `./tools/run_tests/run_tests.py --language=python --newline_on_success`? Most of those tests make local connections between servers and clients.

(src27grpc) [root@test grpc_src]# ./tools/run_tests/run_tests.py --language=python --newline_on_success

++ dirname /root/Downloads/grpc_src/tools/run_tests/helper_scripts/build_python.sh
+ cd /root/Downloads/grpc_src/tools/run_tests/helper_scripts/../../..

++ is_linux
++ '[' '' '!=' Linux ']'
++ echo true
+ '[' true ']'
++ command -v ccache
+ '[' -x '' ']'
+ python3.4 -m virtualenv py34

Also creating executable in /root/Downloads/grpc_src/py34/bin/python
Installing setuptools, pip, wheel...done.
++ script_realpath py34/bin/python
+++ command -v realpath
++ '[' -x '' ']'
+++ command -v grealpath
++ '[' -x '' ']'
++ exit 1
+ VENV_PYTHON=
FAILED: /root/Downloads/grpc_src/tools/run_tests/helper_scripts/build_python.sh [ret=1, pid=29889]
FAILED: Some tests failed
(src27grpc) [root@test grpc_src]#

to me it looks like there is a whole lot more required than I currently have dependency wise. This is my python env. I just followed the install for grpcio and it doesn't work. Maybe I need a google cloud VM to make this work? 

[root@test grpc_src]# pip freeze

protobuf==3.3.0

virtualenv==15.1.0
[root@test grpc_src]#

@stevec2810:

* Yes, building gRPC Python and running its tests requires having much more installed than what is required to merely install and use _built_ gRPC Python.
* When you write "I was trying to build a gRPC server inside my network."... have you been able to reproduce the problem outside your network? Do you have access to any machine outside your network?
* With what other ports have you attempted to complete the exercise? You'd have to modify the `greeter_server.py` and `greeter_client.py` files, but that shouldn't be an issue. Is something blocking your use of port 50051 specifically, or blocking your use of a large range of high-numbered ports?
* When you write "there is probably something in your environment that I don't have", I suspect it's the exact opposite, and that there's something in _your_ environment that only you have preventing the exercise from working.

I finally got it to work.
I rebuilt another server, using protocol buffers 3.2.0 and an older version of grpc on a new install of centos 7.3,but I don't think that was it.
In the end I made it work by modifying line
channel = grpc.insecure_channel('localhost:50051')
 
to have the IP address of my FIRST Ethernet interface. If I use any other interface it fails. this is despite the server apparently running on all interfaces see the following.
[root@grpc1 helloworld]# netstat -anp |grep 50051
tcp6       0      0 :::50051                :::*                    LISTEN      26188/python
I think the colons indicate that the server is running on other interfaces?
However, until I put eth0 ip in the channel line nothing works..but with it...
[root@grpc1 helloworld]# python greeter_client.py
Greeter client received: Hello, you!
Maybe your systems work because they only have 1 interface? I need this to bind to a different interface. I want to make grpc servers that interface to client gRPC devices inside a LAN whilst providing access outside on another Ethernet interface to other services...

Do I need to modify this line to work on other interfaces?
server.add_insecure_port('[::]:50051')

I would suspect you have IPv6 issues with your machine. Try replacing the word `localhost` in the channel creation call with `127.0.0.1` first, then with `::1`. Both are technically the same thing, the former for IPv4, the latter for IPv6. The binding to `[::]:50051` means any address, IPv4 or IPv6 - that's known as a wildcard in IPv6.

Very typical processes, such as telnetd or sshd would only bind to IPv4, not IPv6, even if it's using a wildcard. Many systems that are improperly configured for IPv6 would still work fine with very typical processes because they would be IPv4 only. If you are having connection troubles such as the ones you're describing, it's very likely your system isn't properly configured with IPv6, but that gRPC is trying to use it anyway, because that's what you're telling it to do.

I'm seeing the same problem as @stevec2810. Except that even if I specify the IP of any of my interfaces in the client's insecure channel I will always get the same failure to connect.

Similar scenario with RHEL 6.6, multiple interfaces and I don't want to use eth0. Has anyone had any luck debugging this?
#13790 Will surface the detailed error string in Python, which should help debugging these type of network issues in the future.
